utxt.t: … I shall go into Mexico with a pretty definite purpose, which, however, is not at present {wi}disclosable{/wi}.
… he and most of the other area lawmakers contacted said any eventual solution should not result in every document they generate or receive becoming a {wi}disclosable{/wi} record.

pt: {sc}reveal{/sc} {sc}disclose{/sc} {sc}divulge{/sc} {sc}tell{/sc} {sc}betray{/sc} mean to make known what has been or should be concealed. {sc}reveal{/sc} may apply to supernatural or inspired revelation of truths beyond the range of ordinary human vision or reason.

pt.t: divine will as {it}revealed{/it} in sacred writings

pt: {sc}disclose{/sc} may imply a discovering but more often an imparting of information previously kept secret.
{sc}divulge{/sc} implies a disclosure involving some impropriety or breach of confidence.
{sc}tell{/sc} implies an imparting of necessary or useful information.
{sc}betray{/sc} implies a divulging that represents a breach of faith or an involuntary or unconscious disclosure.

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}desclos-{/it}, stem of {it}desclore{/it} to open, unlock, reveal, from Medieval Latin {it}disclaudere{/it}, from Latin {it}dis-{/it} + {it}claudere{/it} to close {ma}{mat|close:1|}{/ma}
